content: Is it true that blood is blue before it becomes oxygenated?

No, blood is not blue before it becomes oxygenated. This is a common misconception. Blood is always red, but the shade of red can vary depending on its oxygenation level.

When blood is oxygen-rich, it appears bright red. This is the blood that is carried away from the lungs to the rest of the body through the arteries. When blood is oxygen-poor, meaning it has delivered its oxygen to the body's tissues and is returning to the lungs to pick up more oxygen, it appears darker red. This deoxygenated blood is carried back to the lungs through the veins.

The myth that blood is blue before it's oxygenated might stem from the fact that veins, which carry deoxygenated blood, often appear blue or green under the skin. However, this is due to the way light penetrates and is absorbed by the skin, not because the blood itself is blue. In reality, if you were to see blood outside the body, whether it's from an artery or a vein, it would always appear some shade of red.

So, to summarize, blood is never blue; it's always red, but the shade can vary based on its oxygen content.
